title: SB 466
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Board of Registered Nursing in the Department of Consumer Affairs consists of nine members and has the authority to enforce disciplinary actions. Any references to previous nursing boards in state law now refer to the Board of Registered Nursing. The Board of Registered Nursing in the Department of Consumer Affairs consists of nine members and has the authority to enforce disciplinary actions. Section 2708 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to appoint an executive officer who must be a licensed nurse and possess specific qualifications determined by the board. The executive officer shall not be a board member. This section will be repealed on January 1, 2018, unless extended by a later statute. Section 2718 of the Business and Professions Code requires the board to contract with the office for a performance audit of the enforcement program by February 1, 2016. The audit results and recommendations must be reported to the Governor and Legislature by January 1, 2017. The board is required to undergo a performance audit of its enforcement program by February 1, 2016, with results and recommendations to be reported to the Governor and Legislature by January 1, 2017. The audit will focus on various aspects including complaint processing, investigation quality, sanctions on licensees, adherence to laws and rules, timeframes for resolution, staff concerns, cooperation with other agencies, and backlog elimination. The board must have adequate staffing, training, and resources for enforcement functions. Board staff must cooperate with the California State Auditor's Office and provide access to necessary data and information. Section 2736.5 of the Business and Professions Code is repealed, and Section 2786 is amended. Section 2786 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to define an approved school of nursing as one approved by the board, offering a board-approved course of instruction for at least two academic years, affiliated with hospitals, and an institution of higher education. This includes community colleges and private postsecondary institutions offering specific degrees. A school of nursing affiliated with an institution subject to the California Private Postsecondary Education Act of 2009 may be approved by the board to grant associate or baccalaureate degrees in nursing with additional study as approved by the board and institution. The board determines required subjects for nursing licensure, including theory and clinical experience. Regulations ensure schools provide comprehensive clinical instruction. Analysis of registered nurse practice conducted every five years to inform instruction requirements and licensing examination validation. The board will deny or revoke approval for nursing schools that do not give credit for military education and experience to student applicants. Regulations will be adopted by January 1, 2017, requiring schools to have a process for evaluating and granting credit for military education. The board is limited to granting credit for licensure only, not academic certificates or degrees. The board reviews school policies on granting credit for military education every five years to ensure consistency. Information on military coursework acceptance is posted on the board's website.
